title: Illinois Culturally Responsive Teaching and Leading standards
subject: Teacher Preparation

document.title: Illinois Culturally Responsive Teaching and Leading standards

D0AAB1321F57458AB1C193BD72C894AD.description: Ensure classroom and building decorations are inclusive of all students throughout the building or within the community or city at large

ADA414254B9B4C66BE579F6B71BB7112.description: Verify that course materials are representative of all students, including materials for centers, stations, labs, classroom libraries, etc.

8FD0566BC8F34A878EC7EDACCF01E223.description: Ensure linguistic diversity is represented throughout the building and seek ways to reflect represntation fo world languages

5D448FE2B21348FE82D1F5C48C9445B7.description: Uphold systems of support that create, promote, and sustain a welcoming and inclusive community

18C79ADDF2F148C882CE48DBE5B10324.description: Student Representation in the Learning Environment: Culturally responsive teachers and leaders ensure the diversity of their student population is equally represented within the learning environment. In turn, all members of the student population feel seen, heard, and affirmed. Exceptionally well-versed culturally responsive teachers and leaders provide exposure to underrepresented or misrepresented minority groups, even when they are not present within the population of their school and community at large.

8DC2D419AD654CFD97279AA3E83AF99A.description: Consider a broader modality of student assessments, such as performance portfolios, essays, multiple choice, State exams, oral examination, community asessments, work experiences, social justice work, action research projects, and recognition beyond academia

1037E22CE9CD4D25A2D2BD24DEAA2918.description: Promote robust discussion with the intent of raising consciousness that reflects modern society and the wyas in which cultures and communities intersect

8B8BF1B0B7624CBA9E14AD0B7EA05880.description: Use a resource tool to assess the curriculum and assessments for biases

DD872F799E594FB3BB71237DD78BAB34.description: Ensure teacher and students co-create content that encourages critical thinking about culture and includes counternarratives to dominant culture

11EA78C62E4E4CE890AB28E8CC58AFF9.description: Ensure text selections reflect students' classroom, community, and family culture

1F06F534CCF54A6B922B599CCDC7F571.description: Implement and integrate the wide spectrum and fluidity of identities in the curriculum

1643562340344EAD82D3EDEB2405BC2F.description: Assess one's story through multiple vantage points to gain a whole anrrative that includes all sides of parties involved

74BC684410334407B131A2DB0F93D219.description: Embrace and encourage a balance of viewpoints and perspectives that leverage asset thinking toward traditionally marginalized populations

1641EC06D2A848659CDF5D1BD3D71A7B.description: Ensure assessments reflect the enriched curriculum that has embedded student identities

E2F6D759D233462AB899D26F05E38310.description: Employ authentic and modern technology usage inspiring digital literacy through an equity lens

CF00BBD36BE744F7BB979E101146DAEE.description: Identify and articulate the purposeful ways in which marginalized communities are representated in curriculum, including print, digital media, and other classroom resources

4829E1517DA949B78CD7A25942647796.description: Content Selections in all Curricula: Culturally responsive teachers and leaders intentionally embrace student identities and prioritize representation in the curriculum. In turn, students are not only given a chance to identify with the curriculum, they become exposed to other cultures within their schoosl and both their local and global communities.

FAD5264A47054A80AED3E3FFD6711186.description: Collaborate effectively over time with the local community and community agencies, when adn where appropriate, to promote a positive environment for student learning

72801CD5C1754849BD02CE2C2C3668B1.description: Communicat eand provide appropriate techniques and materials to support and enrich student learning at home

A31DB6A34836489D9791DA302084F290.description: Welcome communication from parents and reply in a timely manner

EDCB2D270D964CA6A3027A48931C54CB.description: Invite family and community members to teach about topics that are culturally specific and aligned to the classroom curriculum or content area

5AC3F5F106E44FAFA4A54E1DA2418760.description: Foster students' cultural understanding and connection to the surrounding community

D5E456D8647A4058A744E0283482F2CB.description: Develop relationships with families and the community outside of the classroom setting

9C411BA4307247978F8A1CDBFC34EE75.description: Use best practices that are culturally responsive to value students and their families' cultural traditions when recognizing, motivating, encouraging, and supporting student success and growth

549C903F13EC4182B793294ABDDF1E88.description: Continuously learn and build cultural knowledge that families and the community bring to the school community to nurture and foster relationships and inform student learning experiences

CB63961A4BB54C95B1B91AD80C725C60.description: Forge ongoing participation with families and community members to meet the diverse needs and interests of students

35C85F8FE16745C2878A52118004FAF6.description: Actively seek multiple perspectives and contribution from families and the community and invite them to actively share their opinions, feedback, and concerns that impact the school community

914721B28D744B4C863C23DF75862920.description: Regularly interact with students, families, and communities in both English and home language through methods of their preference

A40028714BFA4BBB8E0481365896F1D1.description: Family and Community Collaboration: Culturally responsive teachers and leaders will partner with families and communities to build rapport, form collaborative and mutual relationships, and engage in effective cross-cultural communication

0DD78870C5DF4D3A936AD22804805149.description: Give students space to solve their own problems, negotiate their advocacy needs, and present their perspectives

7CA5FB319A3846E9B855609DDCAF564A.description: Communicate high expectations to which all students can be held and urge students to lead as student advocates appropriate to the students' age and development

3700918E7BB34873996862E454E5F626.description: Research and offer student advocacy content with real world implications

AB067791B99748548082E4A89E56C153.description: Create a risk-taking space that promotes student advocacy

5A722F520CB74294B0BFE44789D8CD09.description: Help students identify actions that can be taken to apply learning to develop opportunities and relationships for alliances

010EAD433A5F4734AEBA7804BAD45E97.description: Include students in the creation of an inclusive learning community with more opportunities for student expression

04534D0E6AC5448293B9C43AE60445A6.description: Offer guidance to students on how to develop a self-advocacy plan to inform decisions and choices

128098533A81412ABCECD69C0990F201.description: Emphasize and connect with students about their identities, advocacies, and self-interest

15F090E5ADE54DAEA006BEEBF49A1072.description: Leveraging Student Advocacy: Cultyurally responsive teacherrs and leaders will support and create opportunities for student advocacy and representation in the content and classroom

674ED23356F54B138E6D0A3B27B59694.description: Persistently solicit student feedback, value that feedback (resist defensiveness), and adjust based on that feedback

2D1DACA3CABF4038A371311E1341C950.description: Create and embed student leadership opportunities into the student experience (e.g., peer-led discussion, student-led workshops, and student-run schoolwide initiatives)

2C4F6A1BAFE34C84B5B3CCD5D80259AF.description: Co-create, with students, the collective expectations and agreements regarding the physical space and social-emotional culture of the classroom and school

8F854C545B1B48F8B4B5EF1E8E4511A4.description: Consistently solicit students' input on the curriculum (e.g., interests, people or concepts)

1DAC0BED307F423D884A014B64F1732D.description: Make authentic connections between academic learning and students' prior knowledge, native language, culture, and values

E6611C65B1824368AB3CC38B654439D3.description: Encourage and affirm the personal experiences (family, community, culture, etc.) students share in the classroom

4E152F95BA13487DA8E17162724EC020.description: Students as Co-Creators: Culturally responsive teachers and leaders who fundamentally believe all students are capable center learning around students' experiences and position them as co-creators, with emphasis on prioritizing historically marginalized students.

8EA847CA04A84570904F3AF137B01C30.description: Set holistic goals for students that accommodate multiple ways of demonstrating strengths and success (e.g., alternate academic achievement metrics, growth indicators, leadership, character development, social-emotional learning competencies, and school values)

DF3F272EDC864D4D90BB6AD6F5C721DD.description: Provide multiple opportunities for parents to communicate in their language and method of preference, to the greatest extent possible

5199F61213794011BF1E9B9723A2B487.description: Share the classroom systems and policies (expectations, agreements, recognition and incentive practices, etc.) used in the classroom with students' families and align them to the values and cultural norms of those families

E8FEED0601A54B769543572E83B83568.description: Provide parents with informationa bout what their child is expected to learn, know, and do at his or her grade level and ways to reinforce concepts at home

74D6209E1B4048DD87E7535E6FC22FD6.description: Develoop positive, strength-based partnerships with students and their famiilies by learning about them, soliciting their opinions, and valuing their expectations, especially with those marginalized by schools int he past

137B2A30F9C846B8A164CE2C8D3C36CF.description: Engage with students' families and community members outside of the classroomt o develop a more holistic understanding fo the students' lived experiences

9A452517293B44A592CE673579512B79.description: Learn from and about their students' culture, language, and learning styles to make instruction more meaningful and relevant to their students' lives.

AE381EC3F2BD4F55A5CE347E8F6C5CBD.description: Students as Individuals: Culturally responsive teachers and leaders view and value their students as individuals within the context of their familes and communities.

4F9D735AA09F449FB6D7881D5F93FAAE.description: Understand how a system of inequity reinforces certain suppositions as the norm

D2B88152C0DA400B855EE004B5E68056.description: Understand how a system of inequity creates rules regarding student punishment that negatively impacts students of color

2E9E7A8508674FF597AD01A171A77205.description: Be aware of the effects of power and privilege and the need for social advocacy and social action to better empower diverse students and communities

32A440E247E340258F1F866A8EE76F9A.description: Understand how current curriculum and approaches to teaching impact students who are not a part of the dominant culture

75D14A5617EB4C31A9FCC34B2E434570.description: Know and understand how the system of inequity has impacted them as an educator

B38D3427BDC94D948999D3BBA8FA2E41.description: Collaborate with colleagues to determine how students from different backgrounds experience the classroom, school, and district

BDD2FCA09C2E4861B786EE7C17956819.description: Understand the difference between prejudice, discrimination, racism, and how to operate at the interpersonal, intergroup, and institutional levels

EBBD97A7325E4657A6838A3380071AD2.description: Systems of Oppression: Culturally responsive teachers and leaders understand that there are systems in our society especially, but not limited to, our school system, that creat eand reinforce inequities, thereby creating oppressive conditions. Educators work actively against these systems in their everyday roles in educational institutions.

2D9BA143D140408CB446DF2D777D0E39.description: Assess how their biases and perceptions affect their teaching practice and how they access tools to mitigate their own behavior (racism, sexism, homophobia, unearned privilege, Eurocentrism, etc.)

671D5F82851549DD83CFB3F50DA0C3C7.description: Critically think about insttutions in which they find themselves working to reform these institutions whenever and wherever necessary

8154EE6CE42F426299C2EB240EAF013A.description: Educate themselves about students' communities, cultures, and histories

4A052AD018C444B3827D4A84420A7701.description: Recognize how their identity (race/ethnicity, national origin, language, sex and gender, gender identity, sexual orientation, physical/developental/emotional ability, socioeconomic class religion, etc.) affects their perspectives and beliefs about pedagogy and students

D4380582E5904E8C98582DF0CA4CE9B3.description: Explore their own intersecting identities, how they were developed, and how they impact daily experience of the world

CE7F0397C81349F1B612A7D4936F4FC6.description: Engage in self-reflection about their own actions and interactiosn and what ideas and biases motivated those actions

9AD634513B854FD6BCFB77363F75AA35.description: Include representative, familiar content in the curriculum to legitimize students' backgrounds, while also exposing them to new ideas and worldviews different from their own

CC99A984137D4477A3892C18F4A72873.description: Know about their students and their lives outside of school, using this knowledge to build instructiont hat leverages prior knowledge and skills

D0798BC36A8A46009DCA5A9ACE60CECD.description: Approach their work and students with an asset-based mindset, affirming the validity of the students' backgrounds and identities

C0B618121C7B4B3B995A0CFE21A62602.description: Understand and value the notion that multiple lived experiences exist, that there is often no one "correct" way of doing or understanding something, and that what is seen as "correct" is most often based on our lived experiences

A03DE09DE7D94E2196E98EA6735808E1.description: Self-Awareness and Relationships to Others: Culturally responsive teachers and leaders are reflective and gain a deeper understanding of tehmselves and how they impact others, leading to more cohesive and productive student development as it relates to academic and social-emotional development for all students.
